The Register:
Several university researchers published a joint report "Invisible Optical Adversarial Stripes on Traffic Sign againstAutonomous Vehicles" that claims that autonomous vehicles can be attacked by manipulating the camera sensors to cause it to not recognize road signs. The attack system, dubbed GhostStripe, affects Tesla and Baidu Apollo car users. Camera sensors are based on either charge coupled device (CCD)or complementary metal oxide semiconductor (CMOS). Rapidly changing light from fast flashing diodes can cause a camera to capture an image full of lines that don't quite match, and not the image as a traffic sign. Two attack methods, GhostStripe1 (not targeted and does not require access to the vehicle) and GhostStripe2 (targeted and does require access to the vehicle), have a 94% and 97% success rate, respectively.

Tesla recalls the Cybertruck for faulty accelerator pedals that can get stuck | TechCrunchTesla is recalling all 3,878 Cybertrucks that it has shipped to date, due to a problem where the accelerator pedal can get stuck, putting drivers at risk of a crash, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.The recall caps a tumultuous week for Tesla. The company laid off more than 10% of its workforce on Monday, and lost two of its highest-ranking executives. A few days later, Tesla asked shareholders to re-vote on CEO Elon Muskâ€™s massive compensation package that was struck down by a judge earlier this year.Reports of problems with the Cybertruckâ€™s accelerator pedal started popping up in the last few weeks. Tesla even reportedly paused deliveries of the truck while it sorted out the issue. Musk said in a post on X that Tesla was â€œbeing very cautiousâ€ and the company reported to NHTSA that it was not aware of any crashes or injuries related to the problem.The company has now confirmed to NHTSA that the pedal can dislodge, making it possible for it to slide up and get caught in the trim around the footwell.

You are misunderstanding things. It's not a policy. It is a term in a contract.The term references bringing a civil action for breach of contract and what damages it would seek. Declaring things illegal does not enter into that at all. It's about a (presumably) jury finding for the plaintiff or defendant, and awarding damages. Damages awarded do not always match the damages sought.

Epic Cybertruck Road Trip from Florida to the Arctic Circle: A True Test of EVsImagine driving from sunny Florida to the icy Arctic Circle in a Tesla Cybertruck. Sounds like a wild adventure, right? Thatâ€™s exactly what a group of friends decided to do. But itâ€™s not just an adventure; itâ€™s a real test of what electric vehicles (EVs) can handleâ€”and it reveals some serious flaws in North Americaâ€™s charging infrastructure.The Journey BeginsThe crew, driving two different Cybertrucks, started their journey in Florida. Their goal? To reach the Arctic Ocean after crossing the U.S. and Canada. Along the way, theyâ€™ve been sharing their experiences on social media, showing the ups and downs of such a massive trip. The further they drive, the colder it gets and the fewer charging stations they find.Challenges Along the WayThe group even created a website called Arctic CyberTrek, where they share videos, sell T-shirts, and fund their adventure. Watching their videos, you can see that while the scenery is stunning, the journey is far from easy. Charging their Cybertrucks has been a real headache.One of the team members, Justin Demaree, also known as the Bearded Tesla Guy, often posts videos whenever they stop to charge. His experiences highlight the challenges of long-distance EV travel. For instance, they often have to stop every two to three hours to recharge, and not all charging stations are reliable.Struggles in the NorthThings got even tougher when the group reached northern Canada. Teslaâ€™s superchargers, which are the fastest and easiest way to recharge, disappear after a certain point. The team had to rely on public chargers, which are not always easy to findâ€”or use.In one video, Justin shows just how frustrating it can be. He reached a charging station in Yukon with only 3% battery left, only to find the single charger was already in use. He had to wait, hoping the other driver would finish soon.Another team member, Rafael Santoni, faced similar issues in British Columbia. He posted a video showing the struggles of charging the Cybertruck at a non-Tesla station. After multiple tries and freezing in the cold, he finally got the truck to charge.Making the Best of ItDespite these challenges, the group remains in good spirits. Theyâ€™re on an unforgettable adventure with friends, and that keeps them going. In one video, Rafael even managed to daisy chain two trucks together to charge them simultaneously when there was only one charging plug available.Though itâ€™s been tough, their journey is a testament to the potentialâ€”and current limitationsâ€”of electric vehicles. Theyâ€™re pushing the boundaries of whatâ€™s possible, showing that EVs can handle even the most extreme conditions, though thereâ€™s clearly room for improvement in charging infrastructure.

Engineer shows he has no self-esteem by applying 300 times to TeslaPhoto by on Bob Minge is an engineer with big dreams. He wants to work for Tesla. Minge explains, â€œEver since I was a little boy, Iâ€™ve had this dream of working my ass off for no benefits. You know. The American dream kinda thing. When I graduated, I realized that Tesla would be the perfect place for me to waste my life away.â€Minge got to task as soon as he graduated. He started using AI to polish his resume. He told us, â€œSure, the AI made it sound like I had experience flying to the moon, and rising emus in Antarctica, but â€˜fake it, â€™til you make it!â€™ Am I right? Iâ€™m brushing up on my emu husbandry as we speak. Antarctica is one rough place to raise them in.â€Minge sent one application and got a resounding â€œfuck, no!â€ However, not one to take â€œfuck, no!â€ for an answer, he persisted and sent 300 applications before he finally got a â€œwhy not?â€ answer. When we asked Tesla for a comment they replied that they got tired of answering â€œfuck, no!â€, and they figured they could probably abuse someone so oblivious to rejection.However, his ordeal was far from over. â€œThis just landed me the first interview. I could clearly see by the way they were vomiting during the interview that I would not get the job.â€ So he continued applying. He went to interview after interview, causing many lunches to be returned to sender. Eventually, he landed a total of 10 interviews.We asked him about his reasoning for being so persistent. He told us, â€œWell, people with more self-esteem than I do would eventually give up on their dream job. Not everybody is made to perform a dull job with no benefits, and always in fear of pissing off the CEO or being fired, but I am.â€Ultimately, Minge landed a job at Tesla as a floor buffer. He admitted, â€œItâ€™s a menial job, but it is a start.â€ The article that inspired this satire:

In 2008 koos ik een Toyota Prius Tech, in 2012 een Volvo C30 D2 R-Edition, in 2016 een Volvo V40 D3 Cross-Country, en in 2020 wilde ik per se elektrisch gaan rijden maar helaas paste een Polestar 2 niet in mijn leasebudget... Een Tesla Model 3 SR+ wel, dus was het die geworden, en dat was toen ook gewoon met kop en schouders de beste elektrische auto op de markt.Ondertussen hebben andere fabrikanten flink aan de weg getimmerd om het gat met de Model 3 te dichten... Maar eigenlijk zijn ze er allemaal nog net niet. Als je bijvoorbeeld de Model 3 Standard Range vergelijkt met de EX30 Extended Range, heeft die EX30 een 10% grotere accu dan de Model 3, maar heeft de Model 3 daarmee toch een 15% groter bereik en die laadt ook nog eens 10% sneller. Onder aan de streep is de Model 3 toch nog steeds de beste elektrische auto op de markt.Maar dan die Elon ... Zonder hem zou ik zonder veel nadenken weer een Model 3 bestellen. ğŸ“Œ Summary:
Uber and BYD have agreed a deal to bring 100,000 BYD electric vehicles onto the Uber platform, starting with Europe and Latin America. The deal is expected to give drivers on the Uber platform access to cheaper EVs and bring down their total cost of ownership. However, slightly worryingly for drivers, the two companies plan to collaborate on autonomous-capable vehicles deployed on the Uber platform in the future. The deal might also face scrutiny from the authorities. The agreement could be a blow to BYD's arch-rival Tesla.

- BYD's arch-rival Tesla recently delayed the unveiling of its robotaxi after boss Elon Musk decided to make some tweaks to the design.

Tesla in FSD hits deer at night and keeps drivingWhy is Autonomous driving so dangerous?You see the deer in the headlights, but it's facing along the road not across it.  In the glare of the lights, you could perhaps see it being mistaken for a rectangular dotted road paint marking.  A rectangle standing vertically (the deer) is visually very similar to a rectangle laying flat out in front of you.Now this 'marking' is certainly out of place in the middle of a lane.  But likewise you'd want an autonomous vehicle to ignore stray paint markings such as in a construction zone etc.Perfect example of why this shit is so dangerous to be 'testing' it on our public roads.

I just finished watching where they unveiled a bunch of things like the Robovan, Robotaxi, and bunch of other things. They all looked fun and nice. Elon, as usual, sold hard. Why wouldnâ€™t he, heâ€™s the CEO of the company.One thing that really caught my eye and freaked me out was the Tesla Optimus.Look at that thing yourself. That is scary. Before I get to why I think itâ€™s scary, let me explain something.Teslaâ€™s OptimusOver the past few years, Elon has complained incessantly about regulating AI. Now, I know why he did and continues to do that â€“ â€™cause he or his companies arenâ€™t leading the efforts and heâ€™s just salty that one of his investments (*cough* OpenAI *cough*) took off after he threatened it and left it. Anyone with more than two working brain cells would know why he wants to regulate AI. He just canâ€™t stomach the fact that OpenAI took off and is leading now in terms of AI research. He just canâ€™t get over it and even filed a lawsuit. He later dropped it. I mean, why wouldnâ€™t he? He didnâ€™t have a valid case. Classic, Elon. Funny thing is he co-founded OpenAI because he couldnâ€™t stomach the fact that Google was leading the efforts in AI research. He wanted to stick it to Google and ended up royally sticking it to himself.He did the same with Twitter â€“ filed a lawsuit and later dropped that one too. He was then forced to buy it. He then decided to spin it off as if he bought the platform for protecting free speech. This is just to show how he tries to spin his failures and make them look like successful endeavors.After bitching about regulating AI all these years, he even started a new company called xAI and shoved their efforts down Twitter usersâ€™ throats. This man thinks AI is so dangerous and yet decides to put it in all his cars, the new Robotaxis, Robovans, and bots.Now that Iâ€™ve painted a picture of what kind of a person Elon is, hereâ€™s why I think these Optimus bots are dangerous.What if the bot trips and falls on your infant child?
What if it accidentally knocks someone out?
What if the bot gets hacked and goes rogue?
These seem ridiculous to hear at first, but they are real possibilities.Now my question is â€“ Why isnâ€™t Elon talking about regulating the bots?The only right answer is because heâ€™s the one developing them. When he does it, itâ€™s fine. When others do it, he goes on to sulk, bitch and moan endlessly, and files a senseless lawsuitâ€¦and drops it.These bots should 100% be regulated. There should be a spec to comply to for manufacturing these bots. Some of the regulations that I can think of for safety â€“
  1. They shouldnâ€™t be able to overpower a young adult. They should be weak.
  2. They should be short.
  3. They should have very limited battery power and should require human intervention to charge them.
  4. They should have limited memory.
I think thereâ€™s a real need to regulate these bots early on. Elon can absolutely not be trusted. Heâ€™s a quite smart and cunning person.

including things utterly unrelated to voter eligibility,
like your cellphone number.After all that is entered, â—ï¸the PAC doesnâ€™t register you at all. â—ï¸It doesnâ€™t even send the user to their state registration website.â—ï¸It just displays a â€œthank youâ€ page. So, swing state voters may think theyâ€™re registering,
but theyâ€™re not. ğŸ”¥Instead, theyâ€™ve handed over their data to a PAC that is coordinating with the Trump campaign. ğŸ”¥While PACs are generally not allowed to work directly with campaigns,
America PAC is a door-to-door canvassing group,
and those, inexplicably, can work hand in hand with a candidate. However, pretending to register people to vote is probably a bridge too far.The Michigan Secretary of Stateâ€™s office is in the early stages of an investigation of the PAC. So is the North Carolina Attorney Generalâ€™s Office,
as in North Carolina, itâ€™s an to say youâ€™re submitting someoneâ€™s voter registration form and then not do so,
which is pretty close to what Muskâ€™s PAC is doing. â­ï¸The problem here is the relative and extreme of American jurisprudence when it comes to election violations.â­ï¸Remember ? A sort of poor manâ€™s James Oâ€™Keefe, Wohl and conservative lobbyist placed tens of thousands of robocalls trying to intimidate Black voters into staying home during the 2020 election. Two full years later, Wohl and Burkman pleaded guilty in Ohio,
getting probation,
an ankle monitor,
a requirement they spend 500 hours registering voters,
and a whopping $2,500 fine.It took the Federal Communications Commission nearly three years to issue them a $5.1 million fine
and four years for New York state to get an agreement from the pair to pay $1.2 million. None of that undoes the damage they may have caused in 2020, and while those fines might be a bit much for Wohl and Burkman, itâ€™s pocket change to Musk.

This past week, threat actors quickly reacted to the Trump-Harris presidential debate and used the topic as a theme in their cyber campaigns. In one instance, they hijacked multiple Youtube channels, including one that has over 2.4 million subscribers, and then uploaded a deep fake ai video of Elon Musk. In the video, the Tesla CEO advertises a crypto event and QR code that sends users to a webpage instructing them to send funds to specific wallet addresses. They are promised to receive double the crypto amount they sent within a matter of minutes.  Some accounts are no longer serving content but they'll keep trying. This is obviously a scam and users should be wary of these get-rich-quick schemes. Hijacked youtube channels: hXXps://www[.]youtube[.]com/@tesla.trump.debate, hXXps://www[.]youtube[.]com/@Tesla.lives.2444, hXXps://www[.]youtube[.]com/@Tesla-i5g/streams. Malicious and fake crypto scam domains: trump-debate[.]com, tesladebate[.]com, teslatrump[.]org. An observation I made as a self-driving car developer:
Predictability of a car's behavior matters A LOT. A self-driving car might be the safest as in cautious, but if people are unable to guess what it's about to do, there will be problems, even if it follows traffic laws better than people. We had dangerous situations because our car was way too cautious when people and other drivers expected it to behave the same way as them.

: "Back in 2019, Musk announced a million robotaxis would be on the road in 2020. They never arrived then, and likely wonâ€™t this time either. Teslaâ€™s share price dropped 8% when markets opened the morning after the event, signaling investors are getting fed up with his lies as the company struggles to sell cars to customers who have plenty of other options. For a long time, it looked like Tesla would become the automotive startup that would make it. But plagued by a self-obsessed CEO, continued complaints of poor build quality, and an inability to deliver new products on time or on budget, its days may be numbered.Elon Musk got used to getting by with bold statements and flashy visuals that might never go anywhere. But his ability to lie his way to success was premised on the goodwill heâ€™d built up with the public and investors knowing they were still going to make their money at the end of the day. His descent into billionaire grievance politics and his decision to lash out at a world that expects him to play by the same rules that apply to everyone else may kill that goodwill once and for all. His fall canâ€™t come soon enough, but will open more space for a future that looks nothing like the one he has in mind."

Okay, so I'm the opposite of an Elon fan boy and a very sceptical almost 4 year FSD-enabled Model 3 owner (granted, in the Australian market I'm lagging behind what is available in the US, FSD-wise). gives a fairly objective criticism of the whole thing. I think the stock market is starting to get tired of the taste of Elon's Kool Aid. I can actually see how the regulatory issues are the least of the problem (a friendly Texas waves it through, California succumbs to peer pressure and public FOMO, and a Trump administration would in a heartbeat as a quid quo pro). Tesla already offers insurance, so it just self-insures it's way to acceptance. It's nice actuarial feedback loop, really.  I still want to believe, but...The challenge remains having an actual viable product. I remain to be convinced that this time around is any better than any previous wild prediction.It's going to require a tow at some point, either due to breakdown or collision (at fault or otherwise). How do you get something without a steering wheel or pedals onto a flat bed tow truck?

In a video shared with WIRED, researchers at the Beijing-based automotive cybersecurity firm GoGoByte demonstrated that they could carry out a relay attack against the latest Tesla Model 3 despite its upgrade to an ultra-wideband keyless entry system, instantly unlocking it with less than a hundred dollars worth of radio equipment. Since the Tesla 3's keyless entry system also controls the car's immobilizer feature designed to prevent its theft, that means a radio hacker could start the car and drive it away in secondsâ€”unless the driver has enabled Tesla's optional, off-by-default PIN-to-drive feature that requires the owner to enter a four-digit code before starting the car.

slowly but surely, the funnest (ja, synack) hardware will be rescued from the storage space and returned to service. this pair of lovely Nvidia T40 24GB GPUs (Turing architecture) will be swapped into another Xeon server for a variety of ML/HPC workloads. a new state, a new house, and all electrical costs included... well it's time to build out the latest iteration of my Homelab. over two decades of technical shenanigans, formally starting in 2001 with a new ebay account and my first online credit card purchase as a college undergrad (who doesn't want their apartment bedroom full of servers?).the full architecture plan is still floating around in the brain undergoing spatial/comparative analysis, but in strong consideration for the GPU workload box is a 12-18U silent server rack with Tripplite AC connected via duct and blower with MERV14+ air filtration. most of the rest will be embedded systems installed on DIN rails with a 48Vâ€”240W PoE++ core network and standardizing on 5-12V via DC/gigE and DC/2.5ge PoE+ splitters â€” that gear is all ready to go, just need to decide which rack.what kind of rack would you prefer, if you were rebuilding your lab?

Rode in a  self driving  in  for the first time recently. It was interesting to compare it with the current   implementation. I was impressed with one event. The waymo was approaching an intersection to turn left, entering the left turn lane. A tesla was on the cross street on the left, about to turn into the oncoming lane next to my left turn lane. The waymo anticipated the action of the tesla and seemed to understand that the tesla would not have enough space with the parked car on the left side of the street. So, the waymo adjusted its lane position in the left turn lane about 12 inches to the right to accommodate the tesla as the waymo came to a stop in the left turn lane. This is not something I've ever seen my tesla do. The waymo seemed more aware of pedestrians and other cars' potential actions in the choas of sf city streets and would make small adjustments based on these predictions to try to be accommodating. My tesla seems more self-centered in its actions.

âš ï¸DO NOT ATTEMPT THISâš ï¸âš ï¸GROSS VIDEO ALERTâš ï¸This Darwin Award enthusiast claims that a   software update will now *not* chop off your finger when it gets stuck between the frunk and the fender. He then attempts to prove it by inserting his finger between the frunk and the fenderâ€¦and the trunk absolutely CRUSHES HIS FINGER.The truth is actually even worse. Elon Musk Set to Unveil Tesla Robotaxi at Warner Bros. StudiosElon Musk is planning to reveal Teslaâ€™s new robotaxi on October 10 at the Warner Bros. Studios in Burbank, California. Originally scheduled for August 8, the event was delayed by Musk for reasons that remain unclear. Many are now speculating about the true progress of this mysterious vehicle.Why the Delay?The event was first announced in April, the same day that Tesla reportedly abandoned plans for a low-cost electric car, a move Musk initially denied. However, later reports suggest the rumors were true. To shift the focus, Musk hinted at the upcoming robotaxi, but fans were left disappointed when the unveiling was pushed to October. According to reports, Tesla needed more time to create working prototypes.Autonomous Driving: The Long WaitMusk has repeatedly promised that fully autonomous driving is just around the corner, but the public is still waiting. Back in April 2020, Musk tweeted that the robotaxi functionality was on track for release that year, with regulatory approval being the biggest hurdle. While some autonomous features are already available, safety concerns remain, as seen in numerous social media videos showing Tesla cars in â€œFull Self-Drivingâ€ mode making risky moves on the road.Warner Bros. and Musk: A Surprising PartnershipItâ€™s unclear why Tesla chose to hold the event at a movie studio, and both Tesla and Warner Bros. have remained silent on the matter. Tesla famously dissolved its media relations department, so getting answers is unlikely. However, itâ€™s noteworthy that Warner Bros. is partnering with Musk, a figure who has become increasingly politically divisive. Once viewed as an innovative tech leader, Muskâ€™s recent alignment with controversial figures like Donald Trump has changed his public image.Weâ€™ll see if the October event goes ahead as plannedâ€”or if it gets delayed once more.

Elon Musk is attacking the core foundations of American democracy on multiple fronts. â™¦ï¸Thereâ€™s his thus-far successful effort to get rid of the National Labor Relations Board ( ). â™¦ï¸Thereâ€™s his political action committee, , which pretends to help register people to vote but is just hoovering up voter data to give to the Trump campaign. â™¦ï¸And thereâ€™s his lawsuit seeking to force companies to advertise on X, despite the fact advertisers generally do not want their ads running next to the Nazi content X is full of now. ğŸ”¥All of these efforts have the potential to succeed because the federal courts are broken, and the administrative state is dying a slow and painful death. âš ï¸Immiserating workersâš ï¸Letâ€™s start with the .
Itâ€™s no surprise that Musk is no friend to labor.
He doesnâ€™t believe in unions, saying that they create â€œa lords and peasants sort of thing,â€ whatever that means. When workers at his Fremont, California, plant began an organizing campaign, ğŸ’¥he tweeted that they would lose their stock options if they joined the union. ğŸ’¥This sort of threat is extremely illegal, and the NLRB sided with the workers who brought multiple unfair labor practices charges against Tesla. Tesla also ğŸ’¥prohibited workers from wearing t-shirts with union insignias, ğŸ’¥even though the right to wear pro-union clothing at work has been a legally protected activity for several decades. Then, of course, thereâ€™s the class-action lawsuit in California state court, where almost 6,000 Black workers at the Fremont factory recently got the right to sue Tesla for ignoring at that plant. How massive? Nooses at the workstations of Black workers massive. Of course, â“why follow the law when the lower federal courts are now stuffed with anti-worker Federalist Society denizens
and the Supreme Court just gutted the regulatory state? â“After the NLRB filed a formal complaint against over its firing of several employees who wrote an internal letter critical of Musk,
ğŸ’¥SpaceX made sure to find a friendly Trump-appointed judge in Texas, ğŸ’¥ ,
to entertain its theory that the NLRB itself is unconstitutional. In late July, ğŸ”¥Albright issued an injunction blocking the NLRB from proceeding against SpaceX, ğŸ”¥
saying that it is likely the company would prevail in showing that the NLRB,
which was created by Congress nearly 90 years ago, impermissibly infringes on the presidentâ€™s power. Members of the NLRB board and the Administrative Law Judges (ALJ) cannot be removed by the president. That insulation from removal, of course, is critical, as otherwise the NLRB would basically cease to exist every time a Republican president takes power.Narrowly, Albrightâ€™s holding means that the NLRB canâ€™t go after Musk until the constitutional issue is resolved. Broadly, Albrightâ€™s holding tees up the possibility that the anti-worker judges of the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals and the conservative majority on the Supreme Court will have an opportunity to just get rid of labor protections entirely. Given the composition of the courts, Musk doesnâ€™t need Trump to win this November to succeed at wiping a nearly century-old agency off the map. But Musk, of course, is all in on Trump, despite places like the New York Times pretending the manâ€™s politics are a mystery. Musk has also learned that heâ€™s basically untouchable,
which is likely why his America PAC is flagrantly deceiving voters. There will probably be no consequences for Musk at all

So just screwed us over big time.
The towns in Massachusetts seem to be putting screws in the salt they put down on the roads. My husband's car got a screw in the tire while we were out getting a walker for me for after my surgery. On the way home the tire went flat.
We get home, he calls a tire place, they don't take appointments for at least 4 weeks.
So he remembered he has Tesla roadside service. They come and put a donut on the car and take his wheel away. They want to charge $150 to plug the tire (the previous time it cost $15 at Town Fair Tire).
Well, they wanted to charge him $1500 to get his wheel back with a fixed tire. He said just give me my wheel back.
They closed out his account and washed their hands of the entire deal.
We're left with a donut on the car and they won't give us the original wheel back.
WHAT THE ACTUAL FUCK?!?

consigue desarrollar y fabricar sus primeras turbinas de gas para generar energia... su primer procesador 100% para IA... su primer procesador cuantico... patento su primera litografica UVE... y realizo con exito sus primeras pruebas con luz... y ... etc.

El ritmo al que el mercado del gigante asiatico nos viene anunciando sus avances, es vertiginoso. Casi a diario nos enteramos de novedades, que podriamos considerar cada uno individualmente como un salto tecnologico en su area de influencia, se ha vuelto en la nueva normalidad.

A estos pasos de gigantes, la brecha tecnologica con occidente y a la que fue empujada a apretar el acelerador, es mas que probable que termine por torcerle el brazo y sobrepase al conjunto de los "desarrollados". No hay dia en que no se hagan mesas redondas o no se consulte a algun personaje mas o menos bien informado sobre esto... y todos vienen repitiendo mas o menos lo mismos: Es cuestion de tiempo y especialmente de las malas decisiones que vienen tomando los mismos de siempre.

No es que sea una sola area, sino que China viene mostrando verdaderos cambios y "revoluciones" tecnologicos en practicamente TODAS ellas... agricultura, quimica, medicina, educacion, informatica, tecnologias, infraestructura, robotica, automovilistica, energia, mineria, etc.

Hace menos de dos decadas, China se mostraba al mundo como una simple fabrica de mala calidad al servicio de muchas grandes empresas... pero ya entonces habia comenzado su transformacion, primero saltando a la fama por conseguir en tiempo record la mas impresionante red de kilometros construidos de lineas de trenes de alta velocidad. Paralelamente tambien llamaron la atencion sus impresionantes puentes, flamantes nuevas carreteras, el re-nacimiento y modernizacion de barrios, pueblos y pequeÃ±as ciudades... que muy pronto le seguirian -con igual velocidad- el salto de empresas a nivel mundial como lo son Huawei, , , etc.

Y sin darnos cuenta, hoy practicamente no hay NINGUNA area donde no este presente alguna empresa china de marca mundial. PERO sobre todo, impresiona la expansion que consiguen, el exito internacional y que otras empresas pareciera que necesitan decadas. Hace menos de 5 aÃ±os, era una total desconocida y hoy comparte titulares con casi a diario.

EEUU puede parecer un mercado grande, con una influencia internacional sin contrapeso, pero lo que ha conseguido Huawei no deja de ser casi un milagro. Elon Musk's vision for Tesla's humanoid robot, Optimus, may have been influenced by Boston Dynamics' Atlas, according to the company's founder, Marc Raibert. Raibert suggested that Musk's ambitions were inspired by observing the capabilities of Atlas. Optimus, unveiled at Tesla's AI day in 2022, showcased various functions, while Atlas has been evolving since its debut in 2013, demonstrating agility and versatility. Raibert humorously proposed hosting "robot meetups" between Atlas and Optimus, indicating potential collaboration. Boston Dynamics, known for innovative robotics, was acquired by Hyundai in 2021.

Tesla plans to establish a small LFP battery cell factory in Nevada using equipment from CATL. The facility, located in Sparks, will focus on producing LFP cells for Tesla's Megapack energy storage products. This move aligns with Tesla's strategy to expand its battery supply chain and meet regulatory requirements for local battery production. While details are not fully confirmed, the collaboration with CATL signals a strategic effort to leverage expertise and accelerate battery manufacturing capabilities.

In November 2022, I created a bunch of maps visualizing the EV fast-charging infrastructure in and the . Itâ€™s time to revisit those maps and see what has changed in the past 18 months, as the number of charging stations has roughly doubled in both countries.The maps I generated look at sections of major highways in both countries and categorize them based on the distance to the nearest EV fast charger. From our experience taking an , range anxiety kicked in when the distance between chargers was over 200 km, especially after encountering malfunctioning charging infrastructure in small towns.The maps below use the following categorization:
  • Great: < 50 km from a charger. No need to route plan; just look for the next charger when you get low.
  • Good: 50-100 km. Stress-free driving.
  • Doable: 100-200 km. Route planning is required, but you have backup options.
  • Hard: 200-300 km. Pray that there isnâ€™t a broken charger or a queue.
  • Risky: 300-350 km. If everything goes right, you might just make it.
  • Inaccessible: >350 km. Donâ€™t bother.
Canada In Canada,
  • The number of stations has grown from 739 to 1662 (125% increase).
  • Quebec had good coverage before. Now it is plastered with fast chargers covering all the populous southern parts of the province.
  • The big gaps between Saskatoon and Winnipeg, and Saskatoon and Calgary have been filled in with new fast chargers in places like Kindersley and Yorkton.
  • There is still a big hole around Whitecourt, AB and the highway up to Fort McMurray (which Iâ€™m sure is mostly symbolic at this point).
  • The northern parts of Canada are still pretty hostile to EVs, but progress is steadily being made. Pretty soon youâ€™ll be able to road trip from Vancouver to Whitehorse with comfortable fast charging along the way.
United States In the United States,
  • The number of stations has grown from 4024 to 7675 (91% increase).
  • Almost every interstate highway has good fast-charging infrastructure.
  • The major gaps in Texas, Mississippi, and West Virginia that existed in 2022 have been filled in.
  • The remaining gaps are mostly in Montanna.
Animated GifsThe animated maps really show the progress since 2015. Range anxiety is quickly becoming a worry of the past. For simplicity, the maps above look at chargers with the most popular SAE J1772 connectors. I also did some analysis of Teslaâ€™s charging stations which you can find on , along with all the python code used to generate the maps.

First up, apologies that thereâ€™s been no long form post this week. Iâ€™ve had some family stuff which had to take priority over writing. Normal service should be resumed from next week.And now on to the good stuffâ€¦1. The last refuge of the desperate mediaAhh, â€” the kind that are designed to fool people into clicking by appearing to be genuine user or editorial posts. Always a sign that a company is desperate for revenue, any kind of revenue, and never mind the longer-term implications on quality. Now, ?2. Repeat after me: AI is not a thingMore specifically, AI is not a single technology, and what we talk about in the media as â€œAIâ€ is, in fact, quite a limited, relatively new tool coming out of AI research â€” the Large Language Model, or LLM. Why does this matter? Because (how shall I put this?) less technically educated executives are likely to read articles like , and think that they need to jump on the AI bandwagon by adopting LLMs. These are two very different things: , for example, is a machine learning system designed to automate specific tasks. It learns to do better as it goes along â€” something that LLMs donâ€™t do.3. Tesla bubble go popThe notion that Tesla was worth more than the rest of the auto industry combined was always bubble insanity, and . And this, of course, is why Musk is grabbing on to AI and : AI is the current marker for a stock to end up priced based on an imaginary future rather than its current performance. Musk needs to inflate Tesla again, and just being an EV maker wonâ€™t now do that.4. This is fineIâ€™m almost boring myself now whenever I post anything about the era of mass search traffic for publishers drawing to a close. But then someone comes up with a new piece of researching showing . The fact that Google effectively does not allow publishers to opt out of SGE â€” you have to opt out of Googlebot completely to do so â€” should be an indication that Google has no intention of following the likes of OpenAI in paying to license publisher content, too. And I think the SGE is just the first part of a one-two punch to publisher guts: computers and how we access information is going to become more conversational and less focused on searching and going to web pages. As that happens, the entire industry will change, and it could happen faster than we think.5. Feudal securityI often link to Cory Doctorowâ€™s posts, and itâ€™s not just because heâ€™s a friend â€” itâ€™s because a lot of the things that heâ€™s been talking about for years are beginning to be a lot more obvious, even to stick-in-the-muds like me. starts with a concept that I have struggled to articulate â€” feudal security â€” and sprints on from there.6. LLMs are terrible writersWill Pooley has written a terrific piece from the perspective of an academic on why . They donâ€™t interrogate or question terms (because they have no concepts, so canâ€™t), there is no individual voice, they make no daring or original claims based on the evidence, and much more. My particular favourite â€” and one I have encountered a lot â€” is that LLMs love heavy sectionisation and simple adore bullet points. Iâ€™ve got LLMs to write stuff before, specifically telling them not to use bullet points, and they have used them anyway. , LLMs create content which is â€œuniformly terrible, and terribly uniformâ€.7. Craig Wright is not Satoshi NakamotoCraig Wright spent a lot of time claiming he was the pseudonymous creator of Bitcoin, and suing people on that basis. . Whoever Nakamoto is/was, heâ€™s probably on an island somewhere drinking a piÃ±a colada.8. Google updates, manually hits AI-generated sitesYou might have noticed that Google did a big update in early March, finally responding to what everyone had been saying â€” that search had become dominated by rubbish for many search terms. Smarter people than me are still analysing the impact of that update, but one thing which stood out for me is there was a big chunk of manual actions to start. Manual actions are, as the name suggests, , which means they are a kind of fallback when the algorithm isnâ€™t getting it right. And guess what the manual actions mostly targeted? . All the sites that were whacked had some AI-generated content, and half of them were 90-100% created by AI. Of course, manual action is not a sustainable strategy to combat , but it should be a reminder to publishers that high levels of AI-generated content are not the promised land of cheap good content without those pesky writers. .9. The web is 35 years old, and Tim Berners-Lee is not thrilledThe web was meant to be a decentralised system. Instead, itâ€™s led to the kind of concentration of power and control that would have made the oligarchs of the past blush. Thatâ€™s just the starting point of , and he goes on to provide many good suggestions. I donâ€™t know if they are radical enough â€” but they are in the right direction.10. A big tech dietItâ€™s a long-standing journalistic clichÃ© to try some kind of fad diet for a short period of time and write up the (usually hilarious) results, l tried to drop products from big tech companies, and of course, it proved harder than you would think. Some things are pretty easy â€” swapping Gmail for Proton isnâ€™t hard (and Shubham missed out some tricks, like using forwards to redirect mail). But itâ€™s really difficult to avoid some products, like WhatsApp or LinkedIn, because there are few/no viable alternatives. That, of course, is just how the big tech companies like it because they long-ago gave up on the Steve Jobs mantra of making great products that people wanted to buy in favour of making mediocre products that people have no alternative to using.

When the US began outsourcing manufacturing to China in the 80s, it was praised as a smart business move that boosted shareholder profits. But the short-term cost cuts came at a heavy price: loss of jobs, skills, and the transfer of intellectual property. Now, America is scrambling to bring back its manufacturing industry.Meanwhile, the Chinese government is concerned about the intellectual property of its automakers. Reportedly, it gathered all major car companies this summer, advising them to avoid full-scale manufacturing abroad. Instead, they should only ship knock-down kits and use foreign factories for assembly.

Electric cars are stirring up quite the conversation these days, and itâ€™s not just about their sleek designs or whisper-quiet rides. Thereâ€™s a bit of a divide, with some folks not ready to jump on the electric bandwagon just yet.But letâ€™s try to sift through the noise with an open mind and answer the question: why donâ€™t people see electric cars as the cool new option in town anymore?The power debate: electric vs. gas and incentivizing the electric shiftImagine a classic muscle car roaring down the highway, all power and fury. Itâ€™s a symbol of connectionâ€”the human experience, a cool machine, and the open road. That raw power and the sensory experience of driving a gas-powered car is something many of us cherish.And guess what the best part is?An old Buick making sure the camera got its good side.!No oneâ€™s taking them away. Gasoline cars arenâ€™t going anywhere any time soon, despite the electric buzz. So, why the push for electric cars? Itâ€™s all about giving folks a nudge towards cleaner, more sustainable choices.Think of it as expanding the menu of automotive options to include some greener choices. For the average Joe, Jane, or J, whoâ€™s mostly cruising to work or popping into town, EVs could be a game changer.Busting myths: the everyday reliability of electric carsNow, onto the meat of the matter: the concernsâ€”range anxiety, Full Self-Driving (FSD) tech hesitations (especially with Elonâ€™s track record of promising it for the past 10 years) and the ill-informed worry about EVs in extreme weather conditions among other fears.For most drivers, who are just doing their daily commute, errands, or going on a vacation once in a while, these issues are pretty much non-issues.The fear of running out of juice mid-journey? Itâ€™s becoming a thing of the past. With advances in battery technology and an ever-growing network of charging stations, the average electric car can handle daily commutes and errands on a single charge, easy.Teslaâ€™s newest â€œdefinitely-not-ugly-at-allâ€ addition: Cybertruck being taken out for testing in the mountains.Concerned about how your EV will handle in snow or sizzling heat?Modern EVs are stepping up, with technology designed to tackle severe weather conditions, keeping you safe and comfortable, no matter the forecast. And FSD technology? Itâ€™s not where a lot of us thought it would be yet; but, it is evolving. Even still, while itâ€™s an exciting glimpse into the future of driving, for the most of us itâ€™s not a make-or-break feature.Todayâ€™s EVs offer plenty of smart, driver-assist features that add to safety and ease without needing full autonomy. Adding a splash of innovation and sustainability to the mix, a Florida beach town has recently transitioned to a fully electric bus fleet.This significant move not only showcases the townâ€™s commitment to green transportation solutions but also serves as a shining example of how communities can lead the charge towards a more sustainable future. By adopting electric buses, this beachside locale is reducing carbon emissions, cutting down on noise pollution, and setting a new standard for public transportation in tourist destinations.In the broader landscape of electric vehicles (EVs), recent developments have sparked interest and debate.Tesla, a frontrunner in the EV market, has encountered some legal headwinds, bringing attention to the regulatory challenges facing electric car manufacturers. Teslasâ€™ interior has a look of itâ€™s own that, regardless of my opinion, look futuristic as heck!Coexisting is possible.Meanwhile, Oklahoma has embraced the future of electric mobility with open arms, announcing a significant investment in Tesla Superchargers. This initiative not only enhances the stateâ€™s infrastructure but also supports the growing community of EV owners.On another front, Rivian, known for its innovative electric trucks and SUVs, is gearing up for its next growth phase with a facility upgrade. This expansion is poised to boost production capabilities, further cementing Rivianâ€™s position in the competitive EV industry.As more communities and states invest in EV infrastructure, and companies like Tesla and Rivian push the boundaries of technology and production, the road ahead looks promising for electric mobility.Resources

: The Fight against the Some , Some Shut Down the Power Grid 2024-03-08"For several years now, locals, , , and others have been engaged in a struggle against a â€œgigafactoryâ€ in the small town of GrÃ¼nheide, only five kilometers southeast of Berlin. This is the biggest factory producing electric cars for Tesla in all of Europe. Many important issues converge in this conflict: the struggle between global and local , the question of what counts as 'sustainable' and who gets to define it, the power that billionaires like Elon Musk have acquired and are using to reshape our society in line with their authoritarian vision."Four years ago, the government of overruled popular opposition to permit Tesla to destroy a forest in order to build the factory. Now, Tesla is seeking to expand the facility at further cost to local forest and groundwater. Two weeks ago, a majority of residents of GrÃ¼nheide voted against Teslaâ€™s proposed expansion."According to the law, however, the final decision is up to politicians, not the locals."Shortly after the vote, established an occupation in the forest that is to be destroyed to make way for the factory expansion. A hundred people are now occupying the trees with a variety of structures. Thus far, the police have observed them but have yet to undertake an eviction."On the morning of March 5, 2024, a power pylon caught fire near Steinfurt, directly south of the Tesla gigafactory in Brandenburg. The act of sabotage temporarily cut off electricity to thousands of households in various parts of Berlin. It also halted work at the Tesla factory for at least a week, likely costing the company hundreds of millions of euros."A communiquÃ© appeared claiming responsibility in the name of â€” 'Volcano Group' â€”a clandestine anarchist group said to have been active since 2011. The group has claimed credit for burning a power cable in Berlin-Charlottenburg in 2018 and cutting the power supply to the Tesla factory construction site in GrÃ¼nheide in 2021, among other actions."Here, we present an interview with a participant in the forest occupation alongside a translation of the communiquÃ© by Vulkangruppe, in order to offer multiple perspectives from the movement against the Tesla gigafactory."Read more:

I understand the suspicion towards #, # and #, but the # in this matter is incredible.

America is afraid China has access to sensitive data of American citizens. That's a valid concern, but the hypocrisy here is astonishing. Even if we were naive enough to believe # didn't snoop on everybody in the whole world, # made it very, very clear that it does.

Do as you would be done by
Remember the "Safe Haven" agreement we, #, had with the US, to make sure our data was safe in American hands? Then you also remember that didn't last very long, because America never gave a rat's ass about privacy, especially that of foreigners.

Our "allies", the notorious Five Eyes, didn't even have a problem listening in on phones of European leaders. Merkel's phone was monitored by our trusted allies, to name just one. With friends like that, who needs enemies?

Many US workers complained of long work hours ...
The moves are in part because ByteDance executives believe that TikTok is not performing as effectively as its Chinese operations, suggesting American employees have a lower output than counterparts in China, according to one senior person familiar with the leadershipâ€™s thinking.


So? Sounds a lot like what happens at # or #: squeeze your employees dry. Set very high targets and let them work themselves to death for the lowest wages possible. Unions? You're fired!

Say what?
Apparently TikTok prefers people in some positions to speak #, and apparently that's suspicious.

Several US employees said colleagues who worked on product management and did not speak Mandarin said they were often at a disadvantage because the role required close coordination with engineers in China.


Those companies mentioned before may not push very hard for their overseas employees to speak #, but they don't have to, because English is the lingua franca: almost everybody in the western world speaks it.

Things may be very different if they're doing business in China, they might actually prefer people on key positions who speak English. Who knows, I for one would be very surprised if they didn't care. Wanting your employees on important positions to speak your HQ's language doesn't seem unreasonable to me, tbh.

So...
Let me repeat that the concerns are valid: China may not have the best intentions. But America, please look in the mirror before crying wolf. Lead by example, instead of accusing others of the things you've done for decades.

I almost died yesterday. I saw a Cybertr*ck with a matte black wrap. It's impossible to overstate how ridiculous looking it was.The matte black wrap made it look like an oversized wooden wagon that someone had spray painted black. However tacky the Cybertr*ck already looks, believe me... it CAN get worse.If Cybertr*cks bullied other Cybertr*cks, this would have been the kid who was getting stuffed into lockers. That's how ridiculous it looked.In sunlight, the wrap made it blend with the asphalt road so it had the added problem of being harder to see, but rather than becoming a sleek black shadow, it looked mottled, just like the road below it.This Cybertr*ck was absorbing light because of course it was. If driving around in the universal symbol of bad decisions wasn't enough, someone decided to turn it into a heat absorbing pizza oven on wheels right at the start of what could be a scorching summer. And yes, matte is hotter than shiny.

Just a few weeks ago I was driving on the motorway. I was passing a truck and saw a Tesla approaching behind me. It was going pretty fast (and I was already at the speed limit) so I went back on the truck lane after passing the truck. The Tesla, instead of passing me, followed me in the same lane while suddenly accelerating (in a very artificial manner), as if I wasn't there. I had to accelerate to avoid it crashing into us. Fortunately, it didn't hit us and passed me at the last moment, but that was totally unsafe and weird, especially on a motorway where everyone is already going pretty fast.
Wish I had taken the licence number to report it but I was too shocked.Afterwards I realised that because my car was white and we were on a hill with the sky in front of us, the Tesla probably did not detect us, and clearly the driver wasn't paying attention. Super dangerous not only to themselves but also to others, they should be banned. (haha didn't even know this hashtag was a thing)

Â¿Podria o convertirse en la puerta de entrada al mercado de ?

, y otras empresas de estan evaluando la posibilidad de producir sus en territorio mexicano

Esto podria poner en serios aprietos a los fabricantes de , pues en cualquier caso, la tecnologia y las ventajas que poseen los fabricantes de superan en bastante a toda la competencia de usamerica. activo las alarmas, cuando Musk declaro, que "si los fabricantes chinos entraban la industria automovilistica local tendria los dias contados"

Para contrarrestar esta posible maniobra, ya varios lobyistas del proteccionismo han comenzado a moverse afiebradamente para romper una de las reglas fundamentales del Tratado de Libre Comercio que tienen Canada - USA - Mexico, a saber, que todo el comercio de bienes y servicios fabricados en la zona esta exenta de aranceles en el territorio de los socios... Segun rumores, se quiere introducir una clausula de excepcion que afectaria explicitamente a TODOS los productos que lleven cualquier mencion a "manufactured, developed or have intellectual property of chinese origin" (fabricado, desarrollado o contar con propiedad intelectual de origen chino) para asi garantizar un mercado local exclusivo

Con esta clausula, EEUU quiere cerrar completamente su mercado a la presencia tanto de productos, servicios o incluso empresas que tengan su origen (aunque remota) en China. Esto a causa de un hecho muy claro: El pais americano NO HA LOGRADO ninguno de sus objetivos que se habia propuesto cuando le declaro la al "crecimiento desmedido" del gigante asiatico. Ninguna de las medidas, ni acciones que ha llevado a cabo han conseguido ralentizar, detener o girar el sentido de crecimiento que tiene la locomotora

Desde 2015, momento en que EEUU inicio sus agresion abierta, China ha conseguido aumentar tanto su crecimiento interno, como sus exportaciones y el tamaÃ±o relativo de su PIB en relacion al mundial, logrando p.e. pasar de 15% a casi 19% su peso mundial

Un hecho de la causa es que si bien los productos chinos parecieran ser relevantes, curiosamente el sector exportador del pais representa menos del 18% de la economia local... lo que lo hace mas resilente a los vaivenes internacionales... y el unico sector mas debil es el financiero, razon por la cual el pais ha mantenido una politica de ferreo control sobre los mercados de capitales, para evitar que las maniobras de EEUU pudieran afectarlo de sobremanera. He aqui el motivo por el cual USA de manera reiterada busca que liberalice esos mercados.

I'm in the "I hate" the CyberTruck camp, mainly because I hate it's "looks" and the impracticality of it for use as a "real" truck.However, quoting range data for EVs is misleading UNLESS you also have data for how & under what conditions the vehicle was driven -- ave/range of speed, % freeway/highway vs street use, temperature & other factors that are known to affect EV range.For example, when I was driving my ID4 Pro ONLY on local streets, I was getting an estimated range of 278 which is exactly the EPA estimate for it.However, when I started to drive on the freeway/highway, where I typically drive in the "fast lane" at 75-80 mph, the estimated range dropped to 205.So, my guess is that CyberTruck drivers polled in the article almost certainly driove their "trucks" on the freeway/highway at "speed."

Tesla hasta hace 6 meses era el simbolo del exito usamericano del emprendimiento... Tesla que supuestamente dominaba todo el mercado de los autos de nuevas energias... que Tesla con los modelos mas vendidos... que Tesla el auto que salvaria a la industria usamericana de hundirse en el olvido.

Pero resulta que la guerra de precios ha terminado por pasarle la factura y finalmente los resultados han comenzado a salir a la luz: Sus ingresos no fueron los esperados, aunque tuvo las mejores ventas de la industria y aun asi en comparacion con otros actores del mercado, su posicion parece haber empeorado y mucho.

, el que le pisa los talones ha tenido y tiene mejores resultados globales. Ya ha superado en numero de ventas consolidado a Tesla y no deja de crecer en sus ventas... Â¿Y por que? Pues simplemente no se ha concentrado solo en las clases mas pudientes, ni en los segmentos finales, sino que tambien se ha lanzado a satisfacer a otros, como el Transporte Publico... hoy (no recuerdo con exactitud pero) 1 de cada 3 buses electricos que corren en las ciudades es un BYD... y esto lo ayuda a impulsar su imagen.

Ademas, ellos ofrecen una amplia paleta de modelos y marcas para todos los segmentos... desde los mas economicos a menos de â‚¬10.000 y hasta los medio-lujosos que superan los â‚¬100.000

Hoy Tesla se enfrenta a momentos dificiles, y si no consigue superarlos y sobrevivir... es probable que toda la industria del Automobil en Los Esclavos Unidos, se valla al infierno detras de ellos. Es por eso que hay tanto mutismo en el mercado y en la competencia local.

The playbook that Jeff , , and others have relied on isnâ€™t new. More than a century ago, the railroad tycoons of the enticed towns to hand them favorable deals in exchange for laying lines that passed through their communities. The supposed benefits of these projects rarely materialized:
Many of the promised tracks were never completed, or the routes were discontinued soon after their construction. Worse yet, the towns often had to impose steep new to offset the , triggering a wave of municipal defaults.The trend of unmet promises by corporate titans has continued into the present day. â€™s Buffalo plant has created just 54 cents of economic benefit for every subsidy dollar the state invested, a state audit found;

I know I like to rag on , but this behavior is becoming commonplace in the new world of over-the-air updated . You buy a car with a set of features, but it doesnâ€™t ship with it. But worry not! Itâ€™s coming soon in a software update! One of these mornings youâ€™ll wake up, and your car would have this brand new feature! Itâ€™s the FUTURE!Except youâ€™re not selling me a feature then; youâ€™re selling me the *hope* of getting a feature that may come in a month, a year, orâ€”in the case of Tesla FSDâ€”probably never. But you *are* taking my money up front.I feel this is something the FTC should be regulating. At the very least, require manufacturers to print up front a FIRM DATE on which they will either have delivered the promised feature, or refund the customer some agreed-upon amount of money. Otherwise, I feel like this is just permission for manufacturers to sell a stream of  for real dollars.â€œTesla Cybertruck Owner Gets â€˜Coming Soonâ€™ Message When Trying to Lock Diffâ€

Bit of an rant here:I'm a owner (yes, Musk stinks, but I've literally yet to find a better EV. Honest) and I've enjoyed renting Teslas in the past. Why?
  • The QR code that makes my phone app control my rental Tesla.
  • The easy access to charging stations.
  • The ergonomic layout (You'll see what I mean shortly)
However, for the sake of variety, and because I tend to rent cars more often than the average bear, I've rented a few other EVs and tried them out. I recently had a Niro EV on one of my trips. Kia chose to make an EV that feels like a "regular" SUV. It was perfectly fine as a rental car, it was just not as fun to drive as a Tesla for me. Some highlights:
  • It was easy to use and drive
  • Had all the features you'd expect
  • Supported car play and android auto
But there was no way for me to use a phone app with it that I discovered - that may have been on me though.On my most recent trip I decided to give a shot via their lineup. We ended up with a Polestar 2. What an utter disappointment.
  • The car starts out by having cup holder where your elbow should be resting, because they waste tons of space around their console-mounted shifter. Oh dear. And if you want a second cup holder it's actually BEHIND the first one, and you have to open what's left of the arm rest and flop that into the passenger area in the back seat in order to access the second holder.
  • While there is a phone app, they never bothered to create a "rental" option for connecting the way Tesla does. Oops.
  • While the Android tablet in the console is nice, you have to log in with personal accounts to install audio apps, etc. - not good for a rental. The tablet seemed quite sluggish as well.
  • Because it has an android table, they made the questionable decision to only support Apple car play, and not Android Auto. (Supporting both is almost a requirement in a rental car IMO)
  • The cabin AC/heat fan made a terrible racket as well, with both a cheap/noisy variable power supply and bearings that I can only assume were made from gravel.
  • oh yes, and the cruise control was 1980's "dumb cruise," because it appears that on the safest car brand in the world that's an option, not a base feature.
Now I'm sure that buying that Polestar car for personal use, the tablet idea might be more appealing to an Android user like myself. But it seems to me the vast majority of Polstar sales are to rental companies - and maybe that requires a bit of a rethink? I just never thought - all things being equal - that I'd have a better rental experience in a Kia EV than a Volvo EV.

: "Globally, Tesla has fought off any attempts by unions to organize its workplaces and establish collective bargaining. Signing up its employees is a priority for the United Auto Workers, the industryâ€™s largest American union, and for its counterpart in Germany, where Tesla operates a big factory outside Berlin. UAW President Shawn Fain, who won extensive wage concessions from Detroitâ€™s three major automakers with a strike last year, has cheered on the Swedes and called their effort â€œa blueprint for future leveraging campaigns.â€ Encouraged by this supportâ€”and armed with enough funds to pay the idle Tesla workers for around 500 yearsâ€”IF Metall has stuck to its guns. The strike has now lasted four times as long as the UAWâ€™s in 2023.If Tesla had reached a collective agreement when it arrived in Sweden a decade ago, itâ€™s likely nobody would have cared. For IF Metall, which signs hundreds of such accords each year, it hardly would have warranted a public declaration of victory. And Tesla could have rationalized it as an obligatory acceptance of local customsâ€”comparable to removing oneâ€™s shoes when entering a Swedish home.Now the companyâ€™s approach risks tarnishing its image in a region at the vanguard of the green transition. Scandinavians are among the worldâ€™s fastest adopters of electric vehicles: EVs and hybrids accounted for 60% of new cars sold in Sweden last year. Norwegians, Danes and Finns also buy electric cars at rates far above those in the US. Global automakers are fighting for the business of these affluent customers, who also happen to be broadly supportive of organized labor."

How Do You Put a Tesla Model X in Gear?OVER THE WEEKEND, the Wall Street Journal published a long report on the accidental death of the shipping magnate , sister to former transportation secretary Elaine Chao and sister-in-law to soon-to-be former Senate Republican leader . News of Angela Chao's death first appeared in shipping trade publications with no explanation, then was vaguely reported as an automobile accident;
McConnell, in announcing his plans to resign from his leadership post, said her dying had prompted him to think about the end of his own career. What the Journal reported was that Chao had inside her Model X after accidentally backing it into a pond on her Texas estate, on the short drive between the guesthouse and the main house. According to the story, she called a friend in the guesthouse from inside the sinking car to ask for help: 
While making a three-point turn, she had put the car in reverse instead of drive, she said. It is a mistake she had made before with the Tesla gearshift.
The car had zipped backward, tipping over an embankment and into a pond. By now, whenever anyone dies in a Tesla, the natural question to ask is whether or not the Tesla killed them, or helped kill them. How do you put a car into reverse instead of drive?
The online manual for the Model X, has a diagram showing how you put the car in gearIt shows an interface on the Tesla's touchscreen. It has no label for either "Drive" or "Reverse"; the blue arrows, judging by the diagrams in the rest of the manual, are not part of the display, but the manual's indication of how the driver is supposed to move their finger.
The text explains: When you press the brake pedal when parked, the drive mode strip displays on one side of the touchscreen. Use the drive mode strip to shift Model X: swipe up for Drive, swipe down for Reverse or touch the P for Park or N for Neutral. The drive mode strip is always available on the touchscreen when you touch Controls.Even by Tesla's ridiculous design standards, this is a shockingly bad control system. There is no stable convention around whether swiping up means "go up" or "go down";
notoriously, Microsoft and Apple have completely opposite theories about which way makes sense. And that dispute is only about manipulating text on your computer screen, not setting a two-and-a-half-ton vehicle into physical motion. Tesla's choice of direction
â€”flicking the little car-glyph upward, as if you're pushing the car itself, rather than flicking it down, as if you're pulling the landscape so the car moves forward
â€”is not only the opposite of the way you advance along the road on a touchscreen in Google Maps, it's the opposite of how you drop a normal automatic-transmission car into Drive with a physical shifter. The wrist and shoulder rotate down and back, and the car goes forward. Presumably this had something to do with why Angela Chao had previously had trouble shifting the Tesla into the correct gear. 's design team, committed to his adolescent theories of futurism
â€”and to moving as many controls as possible from physical buttons, knobs, or levers to the much cheaper touchscreen, even in a car that starts at $79,900
â€”built a system that runs contrary to a driver's muscle memory of how to put a car in gear. It's also theoretically possible that the Tesla put itself in gear. The Model X includes a beta feature, which a driver would need to specifically activate, in which the car scans its surroundings and makes a guess on its own as to whether it should shift into Drive or Reverse: When Auto Shift out of Park is enabled, Model X is designed to automatically select Drive or Reverse. The instrument panel displays the selected drive mode when the driver's door is closed and seat belt is buckled.To override the selection, press the brake pedal and use the drive mode strip on touchscreen to shift into your desired drive mode (Drive, Reverse, Park; see Shift Using the Touchscreen).Confirm the drive mode selection and follow the instructions on the instrument panel before you press the accelerator.With your car rolling backwards out of control, simply turn your attention to the touchscreen
â€”because there is no physical button to feel for
â€”stab your finger at the letter P, hit it precisely, and hold it there. What could be easier?

Having tested Tesla's Full Self Driving (Supervised) on greater streets this past summer in my 2023 Model 3, my finding was that the level of effort to be on guard to react and correct against the car doing something wrong, potentially very rapidly, is GREATER than the level of effort to just drive the car yourself. So, that high level of effort defeated the entire purpose of FSD.
Hopefully they'll eventually achieve safe autonomous driving in difficult environments like Boston, but it seemed to me they were pretty far off still despite a bunch of articles written by folks seemingly on the take from Tesla showing stellar results on clearly cherry picked driving scenarios.

Cybertruck with what looked like a machinegun mounted on top, saying he would send it to the Ukraine conflict zone.
